review_title: For the translational research labs ONLY: take this with a grain of salt as each lab is dependent on the PI.
pros: Obviously you will be working in cutting edge research that will give you a leg up for grad school or future career choices. If you want to get a masters while working, they offer a heavy discount on tuition. The labs are usually well-funded so you will be working with decent equipment and the PI’s are well connected. The pay was recently updated so now they at least pay something comparable to other companies.
cons: Where to start? First off, the training is erratic, insufficient, and/or nonexistent for many policies and practices. They have no functional HR team advocating for the research teams so be prepared to advocate entirely for yourself with absolutely no support for the institution. There is no training or policy explanation so it is very normal to be unaware of sick leave or vacation time policies. No one will explain this to you until you’ve broken a policy, so it feels like a catch 22. Depending on your PI, be prepared to experience aggressive shouting, derogatory comments, disrespectful questions about your competence, and no effort to get to know their research team. Some of these PI’s are great at writing grants and the intelligence stops there. No management skills whatsoever. Some of the older PI’s also consistently spew microaggressions or are blatantly racist in their commentary. Overall, there are many other places that will pay more, provide measures to take care of employees, and treat you with actual respect.

review_title: Your experience depends on the lab you work for
job_title: Research Specialist A in Philadelphia, PA
pros: The lab I work for is amazing. The culture is very inclusive, and I feel my best when I come to work every day. The resources are incredible, and the tuition coverage has also been a great benefit.
cons: UPenn is a large bureaucracy, so you have to jump through a ton of hoops to get anything done outside of lab. Promotions and raises based on merit that would typically happen pretty quickly at other companies take forever and require lots of follow up. If your PI is good about it, you can get a raise, but there are plenty of research staff who don’t get promoted because their PI’s don’t want to go through the trouble. It’s like Penn doesn’t want to keep talented research staff around by paying them a fair market rate.

job_title: Post Doctoral Researcher in Philadelphia, PA
pros: There is a lot to learn working a few years in an academic lab, if you can work on new science and difficult problems that involve tuning systems or new method development. These situations are hard to find in research outside of academia, especially in big pharma which is now looking back to academia to do anything even slightly challenging or risky. People not at the top of the food chain are generally pretty nice and good-hearted, or at least they start out that way.
cons: Low pay at slightly above half of middle-class pay levels in 2021. No control over questions, no control over reporting at the back-end (if it wasn't in the original grant the new science goes in a file-drawer or is tabled for the next person), credit and incentives flow upward, know-it-all armchair critics, questions and methods are based on popularity, tradition and appeal-to-authority. Essentially, this is one of the places where real science goes to die (unfortunately, the other may be big pharma industry).

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Philadelphia, PA
pros:
*Great clinical experience, many different studies to work on (industry sponsored, department level, and physician led)
*Amazing clinical team 
*Never had to work outside of agreed upon hours, and overtime pay (based on study funding) or compensation with extra hours off
*Salary & PTO increase after 2 full years
cons:
*The culture/work environment was overbearing, and legitimately the worst part about working here - it’s a cultivated, toxic workspace that is so incredibly draining.
*You will NOT get published on papers - even if you’re told so during the interview, it never happened despite my best efforts. I had to reach out to other departments to get on papers, which is a shame. 
*Large amount of turnaround due to toxic environment, and the nature of this position being a stepping stone to other positions. 

Do not work at PEACE as a CRC if you're trying to get published or get ahead in your career. The only thing you'll get is clinical experience, so please please apply to other departments.

job_title: Research Specialist B in Philadelphia, PA
pros: UPenn is a great place to work overall. It is so easy to network and make connections that will last. There is always room to grow and there are constant education opportunities no matter what position you are in. No matter where you are on campus there is always something going on. Many perks including workshops, networking events, and access to on-campus happenings. The health insurance is great and they matched up to 5% towards retirement when I was there. There is also an annual review which UPenn requires you to have with your manager. I think this is great because it allows you to see where you are doing well and what needs improvement.
cons: To get the position I had, I was lucky enough to know someone who lead me to the job and put in a good word for me to the hiring manager. It is sometimes difficult to get your resume in for certain positions due to the HR system blocking your resume if you appear to not be "qualified" enough. I did not have an extensive research background, but I was thankfully given a chance and I excelled at my position. Another con is the annual "raise" aka "cost of living increase" which is usually only about 2%. I always felt like I deserved more than the average, but it all comes down to funding which is what most labs are run by. It is also extremely difficult to get a raise or increase in salary because HR runs everything.

cons: Mediocrity is not acceptable, seriously.

review_title: Great benefits, wide variety of workplace cultures
pros: There are lots of financial and professional benefits to working at Penn! In particular the tuition benefits are fantastic. In my experience, supervisors also tend to be supportive of fitting courses into your life - particularly in the courses will help you in your position (or future positions you'd like to have there). In addition, there are lots of very practical professional trainings available through HR.
cons: It's a huge institution, and in my experience there's a wide range of specific workplace cultures. Given this, I'd say it's important to get as good a sense as possible of what the culture at your particular office might be - the best way to do this would probably be to talk to current staff about things that are important to you in a workplace culture.

pros: Opportunity for free continuing education, incentives to homeownership in the area, daycare options for kids, competitive benefits.
cons:
I worked for around 10 months as a Research Coordinator in name only. There is a workaround in the employment system that allows professors to hire "temporary staff" through the business administrators and a temp hiring agency called Unique Advantage. As "temporary staff" I was doing the job of a previously salaried "Senior Research Coordinator". I was being paid $15/hr while I was doing work worth $25-35/hr (according to Penn's levels of pay grade). As a caveat, I found out later that there is actually no cap on the hourly wage that you can be paid through Unique Advantage, so if you are ok with not having health benefits, your pay can still be competitive, but you have to negotiate that with your employer. 

I believe this method of "hiring" was used as a way to avoid offering me a contract with clear terms of employment (though there was an offer letter approved by the BA), health benefits or a structured salary within Penn's formal hiring system. I was told that my hourly wage through UA could not be raised past $15/hr, and that there was no money in the budget to hire me permanently - even though I was working permanently. I also had no contact with HR at any point so I was not aware of what I could and could not expect from working at Penn.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator A in Philadelphia, PA
pros: A lot of a CRC's perception of their job depends on their relationship with their PI. My PI is wonderful, and provides tons of opportunities for manuscript writing (I have 2 co-authored publications and am working on one as first author now, with only a bachelors!), as well as extra trainings. I started at UPenn because I had no idea what I wanted to do within research, so I just took the first job that I interviewed with. I don't want a career in addictions (the focus of my current lab), but I was able to gain valuable training as a phlebotomist, with brain stimulation, and with cognitive/psychiatric assessments that I can easily use to pitch my application in an interview elsewhere.
cons: The pay isn't as good as you would think (though it's certainly not bad). CHOP pays much better for similar roles, though that's only helpful if you want to work with children. UPenn also has an HR policy requiring interviewing outside candidates for internal promotions, which is good in theory, but in practice means that PIs will promise a job to a staff member, then do a bunch of bogus interviews to fulfill the HR requirement, essentially wasting the time of those other "candidates."

job_title: Clinical Research Specialist in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Working for UPenn School of Medicine was a mentally rewarding and educational experience. The tools at our disposal and opportunities for growth would present themselves several times every day and that is what made my overall experience working there so beneficial for my own personal growth as well as professional growth. My boss was also very dedicated to the work that he did which warranted our own hard work and results. There were several times where I was presented with tasks that I did not initially know how to complete, but with the amount of talent and skills I had surrounding me, I did not only learn how to do my job, I also got a deeper look into the background of my task and everything that related to it. It was a very enlightening and educational experience for me.
cons: Working for UPenn is a very challenging environment. While juggling several responsibilities and being required to perform above average in all of them, it is both mentally and physically taxing. You will be working longer hours and probably get compensated less than the same position with a private company. Also, since it is very difficult to obtain a position at UPenn (due to the high volume of applicants who are all equally as talented and deserving of the position), you will have to continuously demonstrate excellent performance. Otherwise, your position can be given to someone just as equally deserving of it who will be willing to put in the extra hours and effort to get the job done: there is less job security.
